moves.1. Nc3 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Ne5 Ne4 4. Nxc6: I decide to unleash a bishop and attack a pawn...
moves.9. f4: ...but my opponent is wise to this...
moves.9... exf4: ...so I remove it with one of mine...
moves.10... Bd6: Now I line up the bishop...
moves.12... d6 13. f5 Re8: Time to bring out the rook...
moves.14. Rg1: which is what my opponent does...
moves.14... g6: ...so I bring up a pawn to prevent the rook from penetrating...
moves.15. f6: ...but my opponent pushes his pawn, isolating it...
moves.23. c4 Rxe1 24. Kxe1: ...and we again exchange rooks, driving the king back.
moves.24... Ke6 25. Bg2 c6: I decide to single step my c-pawn, in case my opponent pushes his d-pawn to check me.
moves.27... Be4 28. Bh3+ Bf5: I decide it's worth blocking, with a single pawn advantage
moves.29. Bf1 Kf6 30. Ke3 Kg5 31. b4 Kh4 32. K: I decide to attack the bishop...
moves.36. b5 cxb5 37. axb5: ...and we exchange pawns, creating a hole...
moves.37... Be2: ...so my bishop is forced to act...
moves.38. c6 bxc6 39. bxc6: ...as that pawn now has a clear run...
moves.39... Bg4: ...making my bishop cover its target square.
moves.40. Ke5 a5: I therefore push my far right-hand a-pawn.
moves.41. Kxd5 a4 42. Kc4 Kg5: I move my king to attack the d-pawn...
moves.44... a3: ...so I take a chance pushing my far pawn...
moves.45. d5 Ke5: ...but am forced to move my king to prevent a counter-promotion.
moves.46. Kc5: The king comes back to cover...
moves.47. d6: ...but with two enemy pawns on the third rank...
moves.47... a1=Q: ...I promote my pawn to a queen, so she can come to the rescue...
moves.49. Kc4 Qc7: Now she has both squares covered, and both pawns trapped...
moves.50. Kc5 Bxd7: ...so I remove the one closest to the bottom rank.

gameName: No queens or knights... how will you do? II
